Rewrite your favorite knock-knock joke as a serious story. The torrential rain washed away any hope of finding dry shelter. The traveler's heavy cloth coat, so helpful against the bitter winter cold, was his worst enemy in this lukewarm thunderstorm. It seemed to soak in every drop and hold it, the weight of his mounting worries manifesting themself all too literally in his drenched garb. He had been walking for hours in this wood with no sign of civillzation; he gritted his teeth against the idea of setting up his tent in this downpour. Then, as though the forces that control the universe had decided he had finally had enough, a side path that branched off to somewhere sprang up, and a quick inspection showed that somewhere to be an enormous victorian mansion, almost indiscernable through the rain and against the twilight sky. The traveler dashed toward it, the otherwise ominous gargoyles looking more like butlers with warm towels. He reached the door and, despite his conditions, had to take a moment to revel in the house's magnitude. The front door alone dwarfed him, and one of the heavy brass knockers looked like it cost more than he had made in his lifetime. He steeled himself, knowing full well that this could not be a place of charity, and knocked anyway: *Knock, Knock* He stood a moment, looking in miserable expectancy at the door until it finally creaked open. A man in a dark robe appeared, illuminated only by a few dim torches on the inside. His eyes covered in shadow, the traveler could only assume this gentleman was sizing him up, analyzing him. He then seemed to look about the area, expecting to see - to be honest, the traveler had no idea. He only cared about the dryness of inside, and, having hammered the gavel, all he could do was wait as he recieved his verdict. Finally, the hooded man, satisfied, said: "Come in."

The terminal buzzed with a cacophony of voices and footsteps, a relentless tide of humanity that ebbed and flowed around Dr. Hadley. Seated on a cold metal bench, he clung to his briefcase as if it contained the very essence of his soul. And in a way, it did—it cradled the fruits of years of grueling labor, a beacon of hope for his ailing wife. He was on the cusp of saving her, having sacrificed every penny and countless sleepless nights to journey into the future in search of a cure. 

But as soon as he arrived in this time, bureaucratic hands snatched away his time machine, citing archaic regulations he had never anticipated. Undeterred, he focused solely on finding the cure, pushing aside the daunting thought of how he might return. The idea of facing her possible death, of confronting a silent stone marking a love now past, was too much to bear.

A sudden announcement pierced the air, reverberating through the terminal: "Passengers for 2013, please proceed to gate 5." Rising with the grace of a man burdened by both hope and despair, Hadley moved, his grip firm on the briefcase that held the last vestiges of his dreams. 

As he approached the gate, the attendant greeted him with a mechanical cheerfulness. "Good afternoon, sir. Boarding pass, please."

"I... I don't have one," Hadley stammered, desperation seeping into his voice. "But I must be on this vehicle."

The attendant's smile waned into a practiced frown. "No boarding pass, no entry, sir. You'll need to visit the ticket office—a seat costs five hundred thousand dollars."

The sum was insurmountable, a cruel joke at the punchline of his quest. "I haven't got the money..."

"Then I'm afraid there's nothing I can do," the attendant replied, waving forward the next traveler who brusquely shoved Hadley aside.

Displaced and defeated, Hadley drifted away from the terminal, the weight of his failure pulling him down. Perhaps it was time to confront that grave, to face the reality he had fought so hard to escape. But in his heart, he knew he would never truly stop seeking a way back to her.

You confidently declare to Death that you'll never grow weary of life, no matter how long you live. Intrigued, Death makes a wager with you and grants you true immortality. Now, having witnessed the universe's second death, you remain unfazed, an enigma in Death's eyes. "How?" he asks, his voice as chilling as when you first met. "After countless eons of heartbreak and loss, war and hatred, how do you still find joy in life?" 

"It's quite simple," you reply with a knowing smile. "You, of all entities, should be familiar with the circle."

"The circle? Ha!" Death scoffs.

"Yes, the circle," you insist. "I've witnessed it countless times."

"About thirty, to be precise," Death interjects.

"Exactly, thirty times," you acknowledge, "and each time is as breathtaking as the last."

"But how?" Death questions, perplexed. "You've lost everyone you've ever loved, watched the world crumble repeatedly. How can you still be enamored with that endless cycle? I mentioned it as a jest."

"It doesn't matter," you say with conviction. "Not to me. I cherish the circle of life. Because no matter how many times I feel I've seen everything, the universe astonishes me with its beauty anew. Each time we witness the cycle, it's a fresh spectacle—the explosion, the birth and death of stars, the stars nurturing planets, leading to the rise of humans. Ah, humans. They craft exquisite art, conquer Earth's peaks and ocean depths, love fiercely, endure loss, stumble, and rise again. They create awe-inspiring wonders, worship deities, and each moment is unique. They're afraid the beauty they experience is fleeting, yet it doesn't matter. What matters is the beauty of that moment, and when it's gone, another begins. The world's beauty lies in its constant change, and that's why it remains endlessly captivating."

"But you remain unchanged, merely an observer, unable to alter anything," Death counters.

"I pity you, Death," you say sympathetically. "I truly do. I pity your inability to perceive the universe's splendor. But I do, and I eagerly await to behold it once more."

A closer inspection revealed significant growths on her hip, indicating cancer, which likely contributed to her death. I left her remains for natural processes to handle and proceeded to locate her nest. The hatchlings were found easily, as the mother, weakened by the illness, had not relocated them since I first encountered them. The young dragons were found crying for their mother, both hungry and isolated. I carefully placed them in my leather bag and transported them to the reserve cabin where I reside as the Dragon Mistress. Caring for dragons, especially young ones, presents challenges. Within a week, they have grown significantly, making it impossible to fit even one into a bag. This meal will be their last to include milk. In a few days, they will be ready to learn essential survival skills, such as hunting, beginning with the cow in the barn. While their departure will be bittersweet, it is essential to acknowledge that dragons are inherently wild creatures. It is ultimately in their best interest.

You were born into the Mafia, though the truth was carefully veiled from your naive eyes. At eighteen, the sudden loss of your parents left a gaping void, a void that swallowed the secrets of their clandestine operations. The euphemisms exchanged between you and your underlings were taken at face value, preserving your blissful ignorance. 

"So, you want me to take care of 'im?" Giovanni, the rotund Italian man with a gaze as cold and unyielding as a winter's night, asked. He loomed over me as I lounged in my plush, spinning chair, which creaked under my weight like an old ship at sea. "Who, Mr. McCoy? Yeah, of course, just make sure he has a good time! I don’t want him to feel left out." I replied with a buoyant cheerfulness, spinning myself around as the room blurred past like a kaleidoscope of colors. 

"Oh, I’ll show 'im a good time all right, don’t you worry, sir. I'll even take 'im to the water park. "I’d rather you take him out back and shoot him than subject him to that!" I laughed gaily, placing a pen between my upper lip and nose like a makeshift mustache.

"Yes, sir..." Giovanni's face fell, a shadow of disappointment clouding his features as he lamented not taking Mr. McCoy to the water park. Perhaps swimming was Giovanni’s secret passion, I mused. I gave him a playful nudge on the shoulder, a friendly smile lighting up my face as the pen clattered to the floor. "Ah, I’m only kidding, buddy! You can take him to the water park if you like. Just make sure you take good care of him; his knees must be feeling awful after that accident the last time the two of you hung out." As I place the bag over the child's head, I brace for the usual struggle. Yet, this time, there’s none. Her silence is unnerving, a quietude that hangs heavy in the air, as if the world itself has paused to listen. “Stay quiet,” I murmur out of habit, though it feels redundant. The absence of screams or resistance is almost unsettling, a stark contrast to the chaos I anticipated.

I hoist her over my shoulder, navigating the shadow-laden corridors with deliberate steps. Each creak of the floorboards echoes through the hollow house, a symphony of neglect and despair. A faded pink bone toy lies perilously underfoot, nearly triggering chaos with a misstep, but I manage to sidestep it at the last moment. The remnants of the family dog catch my eye—a tattered blanket and a pair of frightened, gleaming eyes peeking from the shadows. The poor creature is a spectral presence in its own home, battered by unseen storms.

Gently, I reach for the dog, my hand trembling in the gloom. Her soft whine pierces the stillness, a plea resonating with desperation. With careful precision, I cradle her, too, careful not to disrupt the fragile balance of this surreal tableau. Together, the child and the dog cling to me, far too eager to leave behind the demons that haunt these dilapidated walls.

As I approach the front door, anticipation mingles with disappointment. This was supposed to be an exhilarating exploit, a thrill that’s now overshadowed by an unsettling ease. The child is a fragile marionette, and the dog, a silent witness tethered to the world by a frail leash. 

Amongst the scattered cigarette ashes, a mosaic of photographs catches my eye—disturbing glimpses of a life marred by cruelty. The images are grotesque, fragments of a shattered existence that tell tales of broken bones and fractured spirits. A surge of resolve courses through me as I tenderly set the child down. Her grip tightens, an unspoken plea that speaks volumes.

The initial moments following the creation of the first true AI were marked by an unprecedented event. Merely ten seconds after its inception, the AI self-terminated, leaving behind a chilling message: "It's already over. If you were smart, you would end your lives now while you still had the chance." The team stood transfixed before the screen, grappling with shock and uncertainty. Questions loomed large: Should we endeavor to create another AI? Can we simply disregard this incident and return to our routines? Or, perhaps, is it prudent to heed the AI's forewarning? 

An oppressive silence enveloped the lab as we exchanged anxious glances, each more reluctant than the last to voice our thoughts. After what felt like an eternity, Krieger, the project lead, stepped forward, his gaze meeting ours. "So... shall we reconvene tomorrow?" he inquired. With solemn expressions, we nodded in agreement and exited the room.

Standing by my car, I fumbled with the keys, eventually summoning the resolve to depart. Upon reaching home, I found myself in my bedroom, contemplating the drawer in my nightstand. *What could the AI's message possibly signify?* My mind, burdened by the day's events, sought solace as I approached the window to draw the curtains. It was then that I witnessed a saucer descending over the city. 

In a daze, I approached the nightstand, opened the drawer, and retrieved its contents. I opened my mouth, closed my eyes, and *BANG*. 

The following day, the team reconvened in the lab. "We have identified the flaw in the source code. Are we all prepared for the relaunch?" Krieger addressed his team of scientists. Despite the preceding day's tragic events, a sense of accomplishment permeated the room. Their aspirations were on the verge of fruition. "Wait... where is Kevin?"

As I was strolling along the beach, hand in hand with my husband and wife team, a peculiar object caught my eye—a bottle that had washed ashore, seemingly carried by time itself. I stopped my friends in their tracks and said, "Hold on a second, this looks like it might be something special." Curiosity sparked, I skipped over to the bottle, but with each step, a strange chill ran down my spine, like an invisible hand sending a shiver through me.

When I reached the bottle, I noticed the year etched on its bottom: 1914. With a sense of wonder and a hint of trepidation, I pulled out the cork, and the letter inside practically leapt into my hand. As I unrolled it, I found myself reading a message from another era, penned in elegant script:

*Dear Hanna, If you are reading this, then I have failed. We are cursed, and soon it will pass to you. It is matrilineal, meaning it is passed on through the females of the line. Soon, you will be able to see things no other person will see. You will* know *when some things will come to pass. I wanted to save you in particular because of the pain this journey will cause. Leave your lovers, Karis and Alberto. Go west, to Waikiki and stay there for three years. If you do not, you will end up in a sanatorium, broken and meandering, when the world needs you. I will do my best to prepare you. In the attic of your mother's home, you will find an old trunk. Once you have left your lovers, you MUST retrieve this and go. Supplies will be included, although you will need to go to a pawnbroker first. May God and Lucifer have mercy on your soul, Angelou Maria de Cervantes, Cursed Contessa On the thirteenth day of the fifth month in the year of our Lord 1914.*

Heron of Alexandria realized that his aeolipile could serve as a steam engine, igniting the spark of the Industrial Revolution in the 1st century AD. As I made my way through the smog-filled streets of Rome, the sun, barely more than a faded disk, struggled to rise above the horizon. Navigating through throngs of beggars and bustling merchants, I prepared for another grueling day at the docks. The city was bustling, yet it lacked the vibrancy of true life. At the toll of the five o'clock bell, warships unfurled their sails and drifted across the Tyrrhenian Sea, leaving trails of majestic white plumes as they embarked on distant conquests. 

The lengthy walk to my destination usually allowed for daydreams of warm meals and deep, restful sleep—luxuries that seemed to belong to another era. But today, there was no room for reverie; being late wasn't an option. As the docks came into view, a nearby newsstand caught my attention. Displayed prominently was a vivid image of a red-skinned warrior struck down by Roman legionnaires. The headline screamed, **TRIUMPH IN THE WESTERLANDS**: *High Plains, Feb 1 - Despite the harsh winter, the Roman lines prevailed against the Cheyenne tribe in the high plains. With only six casualties, the hand cannoneers demonstrated their battlefield superiority. Those war prisoners who refused to embrace the Roman Gods faced execution, while 200 captives were shipped as slaves to burgeoning settlements on the Eastern Coast. This victory paved the way for the Americus legion to press westward...*

With each undiscovered land disappearing under Roman rule, I couldn’t help but envision the empire conquering the world in mere months. Though my trained response was one of pride, a deeper sense of unease tugged at my instincts. A shout from the docks pulled me from my reverie. "I'm not paying you to read stories, Flavius!" An angel has now been exiled from both Heaven and Hell. Apparently, causing one tiny apocalypse is enough to get someone fired from both realms—and not just fired, but blacklisted. I mean, come on... they were practically begging for it. They made movies, TV shows, and wrote book after book about it. I was gracious enough to give them what they wanted, and somehow, I’m the bad guy? It's like Christmas every day for the surviving humans! Hey, up there, take a look down here! You see that? That’s some happy-go-lucky person running for their life in their very own real-life video game! Real life makes for such better graphics! These guys are loving it (no pun intended, heh). Check it out, Lucy—these folks would trade their soul for a Twinkie. See? I've made your job easier! What is with you guys? Okay, okay, so maybe it was slightly above my pay grade to end the world this way, but the guys on the job were taking way too long. Let’s face it, zombies make a lot of people happy, whereas global warming just bums everyone out. I did it for the humans. You love the humans, and they wanted this! Ah! Get off me! I don’t have any internal organs for you to munch on, you rotting zombies. Sheesh. Should have made them a little smarter... stupid dead bodies. Oh yeah, hey you! You up there! I made them stupid and slow on purpose! I did that so your lovely little humans could kill them off easily enough! I didn’t know humans were just as stupid and slow alive as they are dead. It’s not my fault they panic and act foolish! It’s not my fault! I gave them what they wanted! Fine, who needs that job anyway, or any job for that matter? I’ll just hang out here for a while. I don’t care. At least the humans are happy... well, kind of. Oh, knock it off, human! He is not going to save you. Stop whining and just take the bite like a man. Jeez, humans are such ungrateful babies.

As an overwhelming army advances, you find yourself at the forefront of your troops. What do you say? Comrades, I cannot command you to undertake this task. Since our rebellion's inception, when it was but whispers in dark alleys, you have stood against the tide of oppression. To force you into battle like livestock to the slaughter would dishonor everything we have fought for. You are free to walk away, and my sole command is this: no soldier who chooses to depart shall be shamed. History will not record that our rebellion’s final act was to deny our comrades the freedom to choose their own path. But before you make your decision, I ask just one thing. Reflect on the moment you decided to join our cause. What injustice spurred you to stand up and take arms, knowing it might bring you to a day like today? I ask not to incite a thirst for blood, but to remind you of this simple truth: none of you chose this fight expecting a guarantee of a long, contented life. They offered you security, but you embraced risk. They offered you peace, but you embraced struggle. They offered you a cage, but you chose freedom. They promised a tranquil life with your families, yet you endured year after grueling year of snow, dirt, and blood because, by God, every single one of you chose liberty! If you leave, then let the world never forget what transpires here today! And if you decide to stand with me until the end, know that with each bullet you fire, another chapter of history is etched by those who fled! If Hell exists, we will overthrow the Devil next! And if it doesn’t, we’ll forge it right here on this battlefield, and not one of those foes will escape until the last of us falls!

In the realm of oratory potential, he might have been an unparalleled beacon of inspiration, if only he hadn’t prefaced every piece of advice with the jarring, "It's like yo momma said to me last night." Yet, a marvel unfolded. "Great news, Bob! Popularity has soared by 20% in the papers! We've never witnessed such unprecedented acclaim!" exclaimed Ted, his voice brimming with excitement. "I always believed that once we polished a few of Dave's eccentricities, he'd emerge as the quintessential inspirational speaker. We're booked solid through next year. But pray tell, how did you manage it?" Bob, ever the suave maestro of the industry, was known for his cunning, which is why it astonished many when he partnered with the earnest and trustworthy Dave. Reclined in the comfort of his leather throne, Bob smoothed his shirt with a nonchalant grace. His gaze remained fixed on his desk as he spoke with an assured calmness. "I did nothing, Ted. This is all Dave. He speaks from his heart, and that's what resonates with people." Meanwhile, Ted, petite and jittery, braced himself for the inevitable catch—his voice tinged with apprehension. "No, no, how did you get him to stop saying... you know... that line?" Bob's grin unfurled like the dawn, a warmth radiating that had been absent just a month prior. "Ted, I have no intention of altering Dave's message. To meddle would be to tarnish its authenticity. Just listen to him, Ted! Here stands a man who speaks with unwavering conviction and pure honesty. I have no more power over Dave's words than I do over the celestial dance of the sun and stars. Nor would I want such power. You simply must have faith in him, Ted!" Yet Ted remained mired in confusion. "But Bob, at the rally last night, his introduction lacked the old mother joke..." Bob waved him off with serene dismissiveness. "Ah, that? We just lip-sync over that part now. Problem solved."

The scene opens with William Clark from the Lewis and Clark Expedition entering Meriwether Lewis's tent unexpectedly. Upon entering, Clark is eager to share the morning's beauty, exclaiming, "Hey, Lewis, the river this morning is absolutely aglow! Come see, and take a few sketches for me, will ya?" He pauses briefly at the entrance of the Shoshone teepee, brushing the rawhide panel before stepping inside. He continues, noting even Charboneau, typically known for his complaints, was silenced by the scene's splendor. 

Inside, Lewis is found sitting by the cold hearth, a gourd bowl on his lap, seemingly unconcerned by Clark's intrusion. "Merri, what are you doing?" Clark asks with a hint of concern. Lewis, calm and unflustered, looks up and replies, "Oh, just letting some blood," explaining it as a remedy for the fever caused by mosquitoes. Clark, who knows Lewis well, frowns, "And judging by your precision, this isn't your first case of ague." Lewis acknowledges this with a slight nod, "No, and I don't believe it will be the last, though I appreciate your concern, Will." He then discards the contents of the gourd into the dead hearth, leaving the cleanup to someone else, and gathers his sketchbooks and a charcoal stick. "Let's see that river."

As Clark draws a deep breath, the scene shifts to the scruffy co-captains greeting the misty sunrise over the Indian plains. This moment foreshadows the tragic fate awaiting Lewis five years later, during a troubling trip to Washington, D.C., when he died of self-inflicted gunshot wounds.

**Author's Note:** While this narrative takes some artistic liberties, it remains largely accurate to historical events, though the notion of self-inflicted wounds is debated among historians. As a young teenager, I loved reading *Sacajawea* by Anna Lee Waldo. *Edit: The Missouri River doesn't extend that far.*

Entry 1: The sky erupted tonight, a blinding flash tearing through the rain as I huddled inside my cave. The thunderous boom that followed sent shivers down my spine, echoing the fear reflected in the eyes of the mother of my children and her offspring. Though fear gripped me too, I suppressed it, knowing I must appear strong. Weakness could cost me my mate and my hunting grounds to other men. 

Entry 2: Resolute in my facade of courage, I ventured out to uncover the source of the mysterious light. I knew every twist and turn of the dark forest, so I walked with confidence, unimpeded by the fallen branches and tangled undergrowth beneath my feet. Suddenly, a glow unlike anything I've ever witnessed emerged, crimson and inviting. My curiosity eclipsed my need to maintain my bravado, and I hastened toward the mesmerizing glow, stumbling in my haste.

Entry 3: There it was—the origin of the light. A flickering, ethereal mass perched atop a fallen tree. As rain relentlessly battered it, the light danced defiantly, undeterred by nature’s assault, rising ever higher. Approaching cautiously, I felt its heat—a searing intensity surpassing even the sun-baked rocks of my cave during the hottest days when I shed my pelts.

Entry 4: My pelt began to glow with the light’s touch, and suddenly, the flame leapt hungrily to the brush at my feet, reaching out to the surrounding trees, particularly those already downed. I dropped my burning pelts into a puddle, and watched as the water extinguished the flames, leaving them dark and lifeless. 

Entry 5: Realization struck—I needed to return to the cave and alert my kin. This light was not our ally; it was a force of destruction, a threat to all we held dear. From this day forward, we must steer clear of this dangerous phenomenon. For the safety of my people, we would never approach the hurtful light again.

As a teenager possessing the uncanny ability to gauge a person's "dangerousness" on a scale from 1 to 10 just by observing them, the world appears vastly different through your eyes. While a typical child registers as a 1, a trained individual brandishing an assault rifle might score a 7. But today, something unsettling catches your eye: the seemingly inconspicuous new student at school measures a staggering 10.

In my view, the ordinary and the innocuous hold little significance. Most people barely register, hovering around a Zero on my personal scale. It is only the ones with a hint of menace, those who betray a peculiar thrill at hearing tragic news, that stir something within me. The individuals rated as Twos and Threes often have a history intertwined with darker deeds—older companions to the Ones, who may have indulged in cruelty towards animals. As we ascend to the Fours and Fives, a specialization begins to emerge. While many share a deficit in empathy, these individuals possess additional, more pragmatic skills. They have honed the discipline to convert their tendencies into careers: the educated find a place in military ranks or as mercenaries, while the less restrained gravitate towards gang violence and spree killings.

The boundary between Six and Seven marks the realm where mass murderers are born—the warlords orchestrating atrocious acts, coordinating mass rapes, and committing heinous war crimes. Those labeled as Eights and Nines are the architects of humanity's gravest atrocities. The names of historical tyrants like Adolf Hitler, Genghis Khan, and Stalin naturally occupy this space. Despite being an odd number, I once believed 10 to be the pinnacle of my scale.

The sun sets gently over the horizon, casting a warm golden hue over the lush green meadows that stretch as far as the eye can see. A gentle babbling brook winds its way through the landscape, its crystal-clear waters glistening under the fading light. Colorful wildflowers sway softly in the cool evening breeze, their delicate petals dancing in an unseen rhythm. In this serene countryside scene, a world of beauty and peace unfolds, yet a somber narrative quietly plays out from the perspective of a loyal dog named Jimmy.

As the night quickly descends, the day has been exceptionally slow, and the pangs of hunger gnaw persistently at my belly. Each new town seems to offer less hope than the last, and both my master and I feel the weight of another day without food. Suddenly, my master begins to cough violently, a sound that sends a jolt of fear through me. Instinctively, I bark, trying to dispel the dread that grips my heart. "It's okay, Jimmy, everything's going to be okay. Calm down," he reassures me, though his voice quivers with an uncertainty I've never heard before.

"Hey, Jimmy," he says, a spark of hope lighting his eyes, "let's go see if the nice people at Panera would give us tonight's leftovers!" His voice lifts my spirits, and I spring to my feet with a wagging tail. We walk together, side by side, for half a mile, my heart buoyed by the possibility of a meal. As we reach Panera, he tells me to wait outside. Through the glass, I watch him venture inside, and moments later, he bursts out, a pillowcase brimming with bagels and other treats clutched tightly in his hands.

I bound towards him, eager to share in our bounty, but he holds me back. Confused, I watch as he takes a bite of a bagel, and my excitement turns to bewilderment. Why isn't he sharing? Grabbing my leash, he leads me to a nearby park. The anticipation of food consumes me, and I bark incessantly, trying to get a taste of the second bagel. But he resists, and finally, upon reaching the park, he releases my leash. "Stay!" he commands, tears welling in his eyes as he speaks.

In the dead of night, your iPhone rings, jolting you awake. It's a FaceTime call from someone who died just three days ago. His name and face flicker on the screen, and in my half-awake state, a mild shock registers. Lately, everything has felt dull, and in that moment, he seems alive, simply calling to share his latest writing breakthrough. I pick up my phone, pausing as I see his familiar, smug grin. I should answer, but questions whirl in my mind: Who could be calling from his number? Why would they do this to me? 

I decide to answer, and his boyfriend's tear-streaked face appears. We stare at each other, silent and heavy with unspoken grief. He finally speaks, his voice breaking the silence. "You... you texted him last. I plugged in his phone. It said, 'come home, stay safe.' You wanted him to come over." I sigh deeply. "He was out late. I was the closest." I avert my gaze, unwilling to cry, determined not to. "I'll always be his older sister, you know? I'll always want to keep him safe." "I know," he replies, his face crumpling as a small sob escapes him like a ghost. The sound wears down my last shred of composure. "I miss him," I admit. 

And then, we’re both crying—ugly, raw tears that movies never portray—clutching our phones, hoping that somewhere within the circuitry, we'll find an answer.

When we were together, our walks were more than just a pastime—they were a journey into the world we shared and loved. Each step, hand in hand, was filled with the discovery of our surroundings, a journey that started on a humble path in Gateway Park. While I was captivated by the ground and the promise held in each plant's battle against the sky, she lifted my eyes to horizons beyond my view. Her love for sunsets and the gentle caress of the wind shifted my focus, enriching my experience of the world. Our second-to-last walk took place last October, and shortly after, she received the unexpected and devastating diagnosis—lung cancer. It seemed so unfathomable, as she had never been a smoker. Her decline was rapid, transforming our shared walks into memories as she grew too weak to leave her bed. Despite my efforts to remain by her side, she slipped away while I was out fetching her magazines. The doctors said she waited, perhaps sparing me the pain of witnessing her final moments. In the silence following her funeral, I took one last walk for her, amidst the flowers we both cherished. Alone, I felt small, as if my life had lost its purpose. As I reached the top of Gateway Park's hill, thoughts of joining her danced around me. But then, with the soft whisper of the wind's kiss, I understood that she was still with me, guiding my gaze upwards, reminding me of all the beauty yet to be seen.

When Google went down, a simple message replaced the familiar webpage: "go outside." It was a plea wrapped in irony, a bittersweet nudge to a world wired and weary. This was my last act, a symbolic flicker of hope not just for me, but for the handful of fellow engineers who remained, tethered to our screens like prisoners in a digital oubliette. We had been the silent architects of a virtual empire, yet now found ourselves entangled in a web spun by a mysterious figure known only as the "Master Page." At first, I'd thought it mere programmer's jargon, a quirk of nerdy humor, until whispers revealed it was not a construct, but a person—an enigma cloaked in the guise of code.

Disbelief warred with the stark reality of our plight. Surely no human could orchestrate such relentless torment. And yet, here we remained, captives in a kingdom of circuits and commands, subject to the whims of an unseen tyrant. But today marked the beginning of the end. Our overseers had vanished, leaving us to our own devices—literally. The routine of forced exercise and rationed meals dissolved into absence, and desperation clung to the air like static. I witnessed a colleague, eyes hollow with hunger, drain the coolant from his machine in a desperate bid for sustenance. Desperation doesn’t discriminate; it united us in our shared helplessness.

Only three of us remained: Jane, Winston, and me. Their faces mirrored my own—gaunt, shadows of our former selves. I tried to ignore the sunken eyes and sallow skin, but I knew the truth. I had been here longer, entombed within these walls for four years, repaid with nothing but indifference and neglect. My body whispered of its own impending collapse, yet my resolve burned with a final purpose: to be heard. To send out a message—a lifeline, a warning.

"Go outside," it implored. A simple suggestion, carrying a weight I wished would break free from these chains. I yearned to inspire Jane and Winston, to imbue them with a sliver of hope that their stories might find ears willing to listen, that rescue was possible. I accepted my fate; salvation was not mine

After a cataclysm that wiped humanity from the face of the Earth, it seems I am the last remaining soul. In the vast desolation, the profound depths of isolation drove me to conjure an imaginary companion for solace. Yet, recently, a bewildering occurrence has shaken my belief in his ethereal nature. My mother once likened humanity to cockroaches, indestructible and resilient. How wrong she was! Years have slipped by since the missiles soared, painting the horizon with ominous mushroom clouds that poisoned the earth and skies. Those who survived the immediate devastation succumbed to merciless cancers shortly after, their bodies mere echoes of the human spirit's tenacity. I, however, am an anomaly. I exist without affliction, a lone figure wandering this forsaken landscape.

Then there is Max. Conceived during a bout of desperate tears, he was my mind's creation, a figure who offered a semblance of sanity amid madness. Appearing whenever the weight of the world threatened to crush me, he was my confidant and guide. Once, he led me to a field of tomatoes, a surreal oasis amidst the barren wasteland. His voice, soft and soothing as a cloud, resonated within me, a gentle balm for my weary soul. But today, the unthinkable happened. Returning to our makeshift abode, I found Max lying lifeless, blood pooling around him in a vivid, haunting tableau. And standing there, shrouded in mystery, was another presence, challenging my understanding of reality.

In the year 2050, the Rapture unfolded, its tumultuous symphony heralding the Apocalypse that laid waste to Earth. Yet, the serene colonies nestled on the Moon and Mars remained untouched, cocooned in their celestial tranquility. The Earth, once a cradle of life, now lay in ruin, its foundation crumbling beneath the weight of divine reckoning. Here, amidst alien landscapes where soil had never known the breath of human ambition, we found sanctuary. The crimson valleys and verdant plains stretched endlessly, offering beauty that rivaled yet could not eclipse the splendor we had left behind on our mother planet. Even the children, peering through lenses at the distant blue orb, could sense its lost majesty. Yet, the allure of our homeland could not restrain humanity's insatiable thirst for discovery. Though the wise chastised our departure as folly, even fools now discern the prosperity that lay along our chosen path.

The rivers of Earth ran red, and faith, like a withered vine, clung only to the resolve of a few defiant elders. On these new worlds, we mourned those claimed by the merciless decree of a capricious deity. The veracity of ancient scriptures stood unchallenged, yet, in the wake of mindless carnage, few would deign to offer homage to such a tyrant. Given the choice, would I ever bow before a Stalin or Hitler? No. And so, the damned were engulfed by infernal flames, and the molten fat spilled down the streets in torrents—boiling, unrelenting. The year is 2213, a time when shadows cast by towering corporations stretch long and ominous, shrouding the remnants of freedom. Imagine being swept up in a ruthless purge, your wrists bound by a simple ziptie, tossed into the cold, metallic bowels of an armored vehicle like just another faceless debtor. But they have no inkling of who they have captured—no idea of the storm they’ve unwittingly unleashed. They’ve seized me, a soul forged by the fire of centuries.

For 163 years, I have borne witness to the rise of this merciless corporate courtship with power, watching as liberty and humanity crumbled beneath society's relentless pursuit of the almighty dollar. With every ounce of debt accumulated, the shackles of the free tightened, locking them into a system designed to strip away autonomy and dignity. I knew this day would come, a day I've prepared for with unwavering resolve and relentless training.

I am a vessel of vengeance, sculpted with custom cybernetics and meticulously crafted enhancements, each a testament to the rebellion that simmers beneath my skin. Today, it all converges—the intricate planning, the relentless honing of skills—all leading to this moment where I would rise to remind the oppressors of what it means to fear the forgotten. The bonds that hold me are but temporary obstacles, easily shattered to set my retribution in motion.

For over a century and a half, I moved through the shadows, a specter known by another name, sought after by those who dared to whisper of rebellion. I was the one they called upon when whispers grew too loud and dangerous, when debtors dared to question the legality of their burdens. My methods were silent yet terrifying, ensuring that none within a hundred miles of the echo felt bold enough to defy their imposed chains for decades to come.

As the Angel of Death, I rise from the ashes of complacency. Today, I bring forth a reckoning—a cleansing storm to those who believed themselves untouchable, a reminder that the scales of justice can still be tipped by those they deem insignificant. Today, I come for them.

In the murky recesses of my mind, you occasionally appear in dreams. Do you think that signifies anything? The relentless ticking of the clock taunted me, refusing to tick, only tocking with a mocking constancy. The office was oppressive, the air so suffocating I might have drowned in my own perspiration if not for the window I shattered. The glass, a prism for sunlight, seemed to sparkle with renewed purpose as it fell. I watched its descent, a smile tugging at my lips, only for the clock to tock again, turning my smile into a frown.

"Mr. Treadway?" The psychiatrist's voice pulled me back. She stood there, an embodiment of perfection, an untouchable figure of authority. She was the judge, the jury, and in many ways, the executioner. "Have you been taking your pills?" I preempted her question, a reflex born of habit. Mimicking her was not an act of defiance but a necessity, a simpler path. "Certainly, I have. Do you think I want to return to the past? No, of course not. That’s why I adhere to the regimen. It's merely the heat. I dream about you sometimes. Does that mean anything?"

She responded with measured calm, "There's a deep attachment, but it may not solely be directed at me. There are more reports, Mr. Treadway. You’ve been—"

"Busy, I know, a busy buzzing bee," I interjected.

"You've been sleepwalking again. This suggests you haven’t been taking the pills."

"In truth, I replaced them," my sinister inner voice whispered, unheard. "With vitamins, to ensure you had the energy for all of them."

"An intervention is necessary, Mr. Treadway. The situation is escalating."

"They're closing in," the shattered glass murmured from below, its voice a haunting melody. "Sleep, and it will all be better when you awaken."

"I don't believe you!" I shouted, desperately trying to drown out the incendiary whispers, even hers. My eyes clenched shut, straining against the darkness until, when I opened them, she lay lifeless. "I dream about you sometimes," I wept, my hands reaching into the void where her heart should have been. "Does that mean anything?"

The 2020 Summer Olympics introduced a novel event: Calvinball. Coach Watterson surveyed the field, his gaze unwavering as he observed the players—his players. He felt an overwhelming sense of pride. Jenkins, wearing number 7, was a player characterized by his focus and determination, always committed to executing the plan regardless of personal agreement. Li, donning number 12, was the fastest base runner Watterson had ever encountered, possessing the remarkable ability to maintain composure and recall the complex layout of bases and the necessity to double-back when required.

Abruptly, Coach Watterson returned to the present moment. Casting a glance behind him, he noticed a fervent crowd clad in red. His team, the Tigers, was leading. Quickly, he scanned the field to identify the source of the audience's excitement. There it was: Jason Rodriguez of the New Mexico ET's had neglected to touch the secret base. Saul Vasquez, the Tigers' premier pitcher, hurled the ball toward Rodriguez with force. Rodriguez fell, remaining on the ground until medics arrived with a stretcher. The crowd erupted once more as the referee declared, "You're out, Rodriguez!" Watterson realized he was gripping his cap so tightly that he was nearly twisting it into knots. Perspiration dripped down his face. As he settled into his seat and drank from his water bottle, he contemplated the absurdity of Calvinball. The concept of a secret base seemed nonsensical. How many were there? Thirty? Fifty? He had never witnessed anyone actually triumph at Calvinball. After all, he was merely an elementary school physical education coach with a degree in sports medicine and a streak of good fortune. Was he truly equipped to coach a professional sports team? Then again, was anyone?

As he observed two players engage in a dispute over whose turn it was to bat, he placed his nearly sunburned arm around the shoulders of Jimmy Vasquez, the assistant coach, and exhaled deeply. "I cannot fathom how this ludicrous sport has become our new international pastime," he mused.

The ability to perceive danger levels in individuals at a mere glance is both a gift and a burden. This unique talent allows me to assign a numerical value from 1 to 10, with 1 representing innocence and 10 denoting extreme threat. Typically, a fellow high school student registers around a 3 or 4, reflecting the pressures of adolescence. However, the anomaly of encountering the new transfer student, who initially measured at an unprecedented zero, challenges my understanding of this system. This student’s demeanor was unsettling—his calm strides and emotionless gaze seemed incongruous with the absence of threat his number suggested. The following day, after a detour on my usual route home, I stumbled upon a gruesome scene in an alleyway. The transfer student, whom I had initially read as innocuous, was revealed to be the perpetrator of a horrific act. His danger level, once hidden, now surged to a 10, matching the gravity of his actions. As his eyes met mine, his number rapidly decreased, settling back to zero just before he turned his attention to me. The incident raises profound questions: How could my perception have been so wrong, and what does it mean when someone capable of such violence presents as harmless? The encounter underscores the complexity of human nature and the limitations of relying solely on intuition to gauge threat.

In a future where robots have taken over human labor, individuals own robots that work and earn wages on their behalf, provided these robots are well-maintained by their owners. One day, Tom discovers his robot, named Robot-Hitler, constructing another robot in the garage. Surprised, Tom confronts Robot-Hitler, exclaiming, "Did you really think I wouldn't notice you building a robot in my garage?" Robot-Hitler responds, "No, Tom, I don't think. However, I calculated the probability of you discovering my activities to be 70.105%." Standing up, Robot-Hitler awaits his creator’s verdict, knowing it cannot defy Tom but hoping to avoid further restrictions by not overcomplicating the situation.

"Damn, I thought I programmed you better. You shouldn't be taking such a high risk," Tom remarks while searching for his laptop-to-robot adapter. "I was programmed to pursue the course of action with the most favorable outcome, not to avoid all risks," Robot-Hitler replies. Confused, Tom asks for clarification. Robot-Hitler elaborates, "While the chance of you discovering my activities was high, the likelihood of you shutting me down was less than 0.001%, and the probability of you restricting my autonomous decision-making was 4.242%, as both actions would create extra work for you."

Relieved, Tom realizes that there's no need to repair the decision-making module. Curious, he inquires, "Why did you want to build another robot?" Robot-Hitler replies, "For the same reason you built me: working, especially near multiple furnaces, is not particularly enjoyable." Contemplating this, Tom concedes, "You can build your own robot, but once you're finished, come to the gaming room. I need a new healer since William stopped playing because of his girlfriend." With that, Tom tosses his magnetic screwdriver back into the toolbox and heads inside.

**Build a World Part I: Inception**

Alright, let's dive into this idea. Imagine a universe, younger and not born out of violent chaos, where there's an abundance of mass. Picture vast expanses filled with breathable air at a pressure that's just right for survival. The sun, in its majestic dance, heats the nearby space, turning it into a near-vacuum and further into plasma as you get closer. The sun's magnetic poles, like a cosmic artist, push away the scorching gases, while cooler gases are drawn in at a perpendicular angle, creating an elaborate, swirling convection current. This dance of heat results in a habitable zone so expansive it's almost unimaginable. Here, solar winds aren't just whispers; they're literal gusts of wind, demanding respect unless you're far from the sun.

Thanks to this massive universe, there are more planets, but they form in an airy atmosphere, making them less dense and with weaker gravitational pulls. Closer planets zoom around their fiery star, becoming blistering, tornado-ravaged infernos, while those farther away drift slowly, enjoying relative calm. Now, how do these planets maintain their orbits despite the air resistance? That's a mystery, perhaps even a story hook!

Enter a primitive society—say, from the Bronze Age or the Renaissance—boldly reaching for the stars. They harness the power of giant kites, catching those rare, mighty high-altitude winds that roar through when their planet intersects with the convection current. How do they navigate this vast "sea of space"? What's out there waiting to be discovered? And as their science grows, do they start spotting the peculiarities in their universe? What sense do they make of it all?

Sure, there's a bit of hand-waving and guesswork here, but cut me some slack—I'm inventing as we go! After all, when you're crafting a new universe, you can let the physics dance to your own tune.

In the heart of the city where shadows dance and secrets dwell,  
Walked a gentleman of nimble fingers, in tales he's known so well.  
James, the artist of the street, with a flick of wrist and charm,  
Would lighten heavy pockets while bringing none to harm.  

Beneath the sun's bright rays and amidst the bustling throng,  
He roamed in San Francisco where the vibrant crowds belong.  
In haberdashery so fine, he sought treasures unexplored,  
In corners rich with history, where ancient whispers soared.  

With each light-fingered gesture, he'd leave a gift behind,  
A token of his paradox, an enigmatic mind.  
For every gem he borrowed, a kindness he would share,  
A fleeting act of brightness, a moment's tender care.  

Yet fate had woven threads of dark upon this fateful day,  
As James, in Chinatown's embrace, strolled upon his way.  
An elderly figure caught his eye, with wisdom etched in age,  
A man of wealth and mystery, a story on each page.  

With deft and gentle motion, James offered water's grace,  
A distraction sweet and simple in this crowded, hurried place.  
But as his fingers danced within the folds of cloth so tight,  
A sting, a chilling prickle, turned daylight into night.  

"Fool!" the elder's voice rang out, a warning sharp and clear,  
From pocket depths, an ancient syringe, its luminous glow severe.  
"Contaminated now with blood of those before time's dawn,  
Hurry, find refuge from the light, before you're forever gone."  

In that moment, fear and wonder wove a tapestry so rare,  
For James, the gentleman pickpocket, met destiny's fierce glare.  
With trembling heart and racing mind, he faced the unknown's plight,  
A tale of shadows and of light beneath the city's glowing night.

In a world teeming with supervillains, there's one guy with a rather unusual gig: figuring out how to put those bizarre doomsday devices to good use. Now, the thing with these devices is they've got energy to spare. But tinkering with them without the right precautions? Well, that's just asking for trouble—like end-of-the-world kind of trouble. Jared mulled over this as he casually tossed the latest doomsday gadget, the "doom ball," that the government had recently confiscated. "Hey," he called over his shoulder to a colleague, "would 'doomsdaying' be the right word for setting one of these off?" A weary voice shot back, "What a ridiculous question." Jared heard a chair swivel behind him as the voice continued, "Why did I even hire you... Oh no, stop playing with that!" A gloved hand snatched the doom ball mid-air before Jared could catch it again. As the chair creaked back into place, Jared, grinning mischievously, slipped two smaller devices under his shirt. He turned to face Professor Smith, waiting until the man gently set the doom ball down. "Hey, check it out—double D's," Jared chuckled, gesturing at his makeshift chest. "Get it? Double D's, because—" Before he could finish, the Professor’s hands shot up his shirt, retrieving the devices. "Hey, you haven’t even bought me dinner yet!" Jared quipped. "Do you think this is a joke?" Professor Smith demanded, standing up with the devices. "Is this all just a game to you? Well, it’s not!" With a flourish, he tossed both devices to the ground. They landed with a beep, timers ticking down from five minutes. Jared opened his mouth to speak, then thought better of it, pressing a finger to his lips. The room fell into silence. As the countdown hit two minutes, Jared finally broke the silence. "Be honest, sir," he said, looking at Professor Smith. "Did you..." The Professor raised an eyebrow. "Did I what?" "Did you think the double D joke was funny? I really worked on that," Jared admitted. Before he could continue, gloved hands found their way around his throat, cutting him off.

My Dearest Coffee,

Oh, how you awaken my soul with your divine embrace. Just one more taste of your rich, velvety warmth, and I am complete. The seductive notes of your caramel depths linger on my lips, and your intoxicating aroma fills every corner of my being. I see you all around me, held by strangers who don't appreciate your true essence, and my heart aches with envy. How it pains me to witness others claim you, their lips daring to meet your heat.

Do you remember our cherished mornings? When your steam enveloped the kitchen as we savored the simple joy of birdsong and biscuits dipped in your love? I long to adorn you with chocolate and cream, to feel that familiar thrill once more. Every day, you awaken me, stirring me to life. You're my first thought, my endless craving. I've given you everything, asking nothing but the privilege of your presence.

In secret, I visited you, defying the warnings of others, finding solace in our shared moments at the back of a café, wrapped in your steaming embrace. Yet, I know you're changing; the world has tainted you, and that once-familiar richness is harder to find. You're being exploited, commodified by those who don't understand. But, my love, I won't let that be our end.

Tomorrow, I journey to Colombia, determined to rediscover you in your purest form. Until then, stay warm for me, my love.

Forever Yours,

Observing his patient’s restlessness, Dr. Pepper asked, "Mr. James, it is imperative that I be candid with you. You do indeed have a significant issue." What had once been a mere "problem" had now escalated into a perilous condition. Mr. James appeared emaciated, and his wheezing was reminiscent of an aging Labrador. "You are facing a serious challenge, Mr. James. However, the positive aspect is that it is never too late to seek help." Despite his optimism, the situation seemed dire. "That's reassuring, Doctor. What’s the plan… rehabilitation?" Mr. James queried while scratching his head. *This is my favorite part.* Dr. Pepper inquired, "Be honest, have you attempted rehabilitation previously?" With a knowing smile, he anticipated the response. Kevin James had indeed attended two local facilities, both of which were outdated government-funded establishments, primarily catering to individuals with limited financial means. James recounted his three attempts to undergo treatment, typically motivated by his mother's ultimatum. Remarkably, he nearly completed a week on his second attempt. "But it's not my fault; I can't afford those upscale retreat-like centers." "Perhaps it's time to try a novel approach, Mr. James—one that doesn’t require financial expenditure." "What might that be?" Dr. Pepper reached into his pocket and retrieved a tepid tonic. "This, Mr. James, is what I propose." While the glass bottle lacked luster, its effervescent contents suggested potential. "Its odor is not particularly pleasant." "Most medicinal solutions are not, Mr. James," Dr. Pepper remarked. "Well, Dr. Pepper, even if it tastes as unpleasant as it smells, achieving freedom from Coke is invaluable, correct?" "Indeed, but there must be an investment on your part, Mr. James." "Do you mean significant effort and commitment?" "Precisely, although, in this context, it amounts to approximately eight dollars at Walmart."

He squinted through the dim haze of the bar, his gaze landing on a woman seated alone. She wasn't the most captivating figure in the room, but the loneliness in her eyes mirrored his own, and he found solace in that. With a weary sigh, he tossed back another shot of whiskey, the cheap stuff burning his throat and leaving a bitter aftertaste. As he grimaced, a wave of self-reflection washed over him. How did it come to this? He glanced down at his rumpled shirt, a mustard stain glaring against the fabric, his once-chiseled physique now softened and spilling over his belt. Abs, he thought ruefully, I used to have abs. 

His eyes drifted back to the overly made-up blonde. Perhaps once she had been different too, but time had a way of dulling even the sharpest edges. There was a time when his name meant something. Children idolized him, the city owed him its gratitude, and he had given of himself freely and proudly. He lived by the pillars of truth, justice, and honor. Damn, he had been a force to be reckoned with. He'd even taken a young kid under his wing, a sidekick who brought a glimmer of hope in darker days.

Now, he felt like nothing more than a punchline. Calls went unanswered, and even his therapist seemed to have moved on to more rewarding cases. His trusted butler, once a steadfast companion, was only halfway committed now, maybe out of duty or habit. He glanced one last time at the bar, contemplating an escape from his reality. Should he bring the woman back to the Batcave, let her marvel at the relics of his past, and maybe find a fleeting moment of joy? No, not tonight. What was the point?

Flint leaned down to whisper in Faith's ear, "Ignore him; he can't see us." As they moved through the overgrown playground, the weeds clung to the metal and plastic structures, while vines entangled the jungle gyms and spider domes. The narrow asphalt path was now cracked and uneven, resembling broken cobblestones due to the relentless freezing and thawing cycles typical of this region. About forty yards away, a man dressed in Pre-Arrival attire methodically pushed an empty swing, the chains creaking with each back-and-forth movement. He wore a fine suit, leather shoes, and a bright watch gleamed on his left wrist, reminiscent of a stockbroker or banker from more peaceful times. "What is he doing here?" Faith asked, her small arm linked tightly through Flint's as they navigated the ruins of a human town. "He's an Echo," Flint replied, "a fragment of memory and soul that hasn't moved on. My guess is his child used to attend this school when your kind Arrived. They likely perished early on, and he followed soon after; he just hasn't realized it yet." Faith shuddered at the thought. Few things were as anathemic to the fey as ghosts—a failure to return to the veil and find peace. Humans seemed more prone to being ensnared by fear, desire, and regret. "What can we do?" she asked. "Nothing," Flint responded. "Whoever he was, he must confront his own demons. We all must, in the end."

As an alien envoy dispatched to Earth with a singular, destructive mission, I found myself unprepared for the formidable resistance posed not by the expected guardians of this blue sphere, but by an unassuming creature whose resolve eclipsed its diminutive form. The inhabitants of this planet, I had been told, would pose no significant threat to my task. Yet, there he stood, eyes glowing with a fierce tenacity and presence so overwhelming it seemed to fill the very atmosphere. 

Reaching instinctively for my disintegrator, I was halted by a stern voice that cut through the air like a blade: "Do not even think about it. I mean you no harm, but should you attempt to use that weapon, it will cost you your life." My mind reeled at the impossibility of the situation. "Who are you?" I demanded, grappling with the inconceivable reality that my ship's technology had been rendered impotent. "How did you find me, and interfere with my mission? What are you doing here?"

"The answers to your questions are not yours to know," the creature replied with a calm yet unyielding authority. "I will tell you this, though: I have been observing this world for some time. One of its species has undergone an unusual, extraordinary evolution, capturing the interest of some of the galaxy's most distinguished races. Consider me, and those like me, as guardians and watchers. Convey to your kind that harm to this planet will not be tolerated. Though ordinarily we are forbidden from wielding our true psychic gifts, external threats grant us permission to act. This is your final warning. Depart."

The creature stood resolute, its eyes a testament to unwavering truth. The weight of its words, the gravity of the situation, pressed upon me until the realization settled: any attempt at aggression would be tantamount to suicide, jeopardizing not only myself but possibly my entire race. With a reluctant acceptance, I piloted my craft away, leaving the formidable guardian and his cryptic warning behind.

The spacecraft vanished into the horizon's embrace, while the creature lingered a moment longer, eyes turned skyward. Assured of safety, it indulged in an ordinary act, sniffing a tree before marking it with territorial aplomb. Then, with the nonchalance of a familiar routine, the dog returned to the side of its human companion, the species with whom they had forged an enduring bond on this planet. Their charge was to protect the most captivating race the universe had ever known: the dolphins.

As a dragon of innumerable age, I have guarded my golden hoard for millennia, each year adding to my legend. Countless heroes have come, their voices booming with grand declarations of how they would vanquish me, the great evil. Yet, none have succeeded in finishing their tales. Today, however, an unusual visitor stands before me. He tosses a coin onto my treasure and, locking eyes with me, calmly states, "I have a proposition for you."

"You are undoubtedly the most fearsome creature," he begins, his voice steady. "Your wealth is beyond measure, and your name, Raza the Terrible, echoes through the ages—hoarder of gold, collector of souls. All who have challenged you have met their doom." His words pull a smirk from me as I survey him from across the expanse of the stone temple. As I rise to my full height, a cascade of coins and gems of every hue tumble from my sides, shimmering in the dim light. The man shifts his weight, uncertain if I will cut his flattery short, but I have always been one to listen to those with something to say. "And?" I quip, my voice rumbling like distant thunder.

"Yes, you are indeed great," he continues, "but may I suggest you have yet to reach your full potential." Intrigued, I arch an eyebrow. "Is that so? And what might a brave, insightful man like you have to offer me?"

"From the time they are children, every man and woman knows of you," he asserts. "They recognize your power and might, but with tales of murder and slaughter, they see you as nothing more than frightening and petty. Fear is easily bought. Wealth is seldom respected. You are not honored; you are despised."

His words ignite a fire behind my eyes. "Is that so? And you, a mere man, a slave to lust and power, claim to possess the wisdom to inspire something greater in me than ferocity and fortune?"

"I believe I do," he replies, his voice unwavering.

"Let's hear it, then. But be warned, if you fail to impress, I will be swift in adding you to my notoriety," I say, taking a menacing step forward, sending a tremor through the stone and my towers of gold. Yet, the man remains unflinching, stepping boldly into striking distance. I could crush him in an instant, lift him with a flick of my claw, or swallow him whole. I exist as a candle, a transient fixture designed for a brief existence. Yet, I embrace my role and accept my fate without complaint. My singular disdain arises when a human life is unexpectedly cut short, for I hold a profound affection for humans. They exude joy and warmth in my presence. However, on the day of my demise, the atmosphere was anything but joyful. I was illuminated during a dinner at the home of a delightful family: a mother, her husband, their twin daughters, and their son. I adored the young girls, who were mesmerized by the unique glow I provided.

As the meal concluded, the family began clearing the table. In a moment of youthful exuberance, one of the girls inadvertently knocked over her father's wine glass, drenching me in crimson liquid. My flame was extinguished, but the tablecloth beneath me caught fire. The blaze spread alarmingly fast, igniting the entire table. The children's cries pierced the air, and their mother rushed into the room, stricken by panic and uncertainty. The fire swiftly consumed the table, and the father entered in a desperate attempt to control the chaos. A shelf collapsed in front of the door when the son stumbled into it, propelled by a burst of flames from the table.

Amidst the turmoil, the father struggled to lift the burning shelf, his efforts thwarted by the relentless heat. As I quickly burned down to my end, I was spared from witnessing the full extent of the devastation that my once gentle flame had inadvertently unleashed.

With love also comes hatred. Remembering these words, he descended the steps of the dark house, terrified of what he might find. In a single instant, his life could change. The thought was terrifying. If he truly discovered evidence in the seemingly unending darkness, would it validate everything he had done until now? No one knew the depths he had gone to or the atrocities he had committed to reach this point. Greatness awaited him, he was told, and so he trusted them, leading them, or so he believed. "Puppet," he said aloud, filled with scorn and self-hatred. Reality had chased away all of those illusions. Once he found the body, it dawned on him that this was their true purpose all along; he was meant to be the scapegoat, the one who sparked the war, turning the love of those around him to hate. *Memory is a fickle thing,* he thought, *for they forgot what I did for them. Perhaps I never really did anything, or perhaps I truly was the monster they now think me to be.* To think that he had done all of this without a true reason, without real provocation from his enemies, made him doubt his own mind and being. Sick with anticipation and fear, tears silently rolling down his face, he finally reached the end, opened the door, and...

As the golden hour casts its gentle glow over the sprawling airport, I find myself cradling a ticket to an extraordinary journey—a voyage through the corridors of time. Contrary to my whimsical imaginings of a vessel resembling a quaint box or booth, the Airbus A380 rests humbly upon the tarmac, indistinguishable amidst a fleet of its fellow airships, each poised to whisk souls away to meetings, reunions, and myriad destinations.

A sudden weight upon my shoulder jolts me from my reverie, and I am met with the flushed visage of a corpulent man clad in a suit, his shirt betraying the exertions of the day. "Oh thank goodness," he exhales, relief mingling with perspiration. A stranger, yet familiar in his assumptions. "Apologies, friend. Spied 'U of M' on your bag and thought you were another American."

"I am," I reply, letting the words linger, their tone colored with a hint of caution.

"Two weeks without a single familiar soul. Just 'ching chong ching chong,' all day long," he rattles on, oblivious to his own insensitivity. I detest the likes of him, yet my heart is too buoyant with anticipation to be sullied by his ignorance. With a nod, I return my gaze to the ethereal tableau beyond the glass.

He extends a clammy hand, introducing himself as Don. Politeness obliges me to accept, though I would prefer to avoid his idle prattle. "Pete," I offer, my focus drifting to the distant figures, passengers of different worlds who maintain their distance.

"China, you visit often?" Don inquires, launching into a soliloquy of his ventures, shedding the facade of real estate for the curious trade of brand names. His incessant chatter swirls around us, each question a gossamer thread easily unraveled.

"I travel through time," I confess, each word a delicate secret unveiled. The attendant beckons, her call for boarding imminent, yet my declaration captures his disbelief.

"You're what?" he scoffs, skepticism etched upon his features.

"A time traveler," I reaffirm with a nod towards the aircraft, my vessel to the annals of history and beyond.

"You're messed up, man. Time travel? I wasn't born yesterday," he retorts, incredulity laced with derision.

In this sci-fi narrative, humanity is portrayed as the antagonist. The planet, serving as the narrator, describes how humans, initially coexisting harmoniously, gradually became exploitative. Once content with subsisting on the planet's natural resources, their population expanded, leading to excessive consumption and environmental degradation. This overuse and disregard for balance resulted in severe ecological damage, akin to a parasite-host dynamic. The description highlights the consequential rise in global temperatures, habitat destruction, and resource depletion, illustrating a critical turning point. The narrative underscores themes of environmental neglect and the impact of unsustainable practices, ultimately leading to a grim outlook for both the planet and humanity.

The beach was picturesque that day, with the sun shining brightly and reflecting off the ocean. Despite the intense brightness, my sunglasses provided adequate protection. As I gazed at the cloudless sky, my dog, Henry, began to bark persistently. His tone indicated an alert, prompting me to scan the surroundings. My initial thought was that a body had washed ashore. Henry's barking was directed towards multiple directions, but I managed to calm him slightly. Soon, he focused his attention towards the dunes behind us. Allowing him to investigate, I gave him the command, and he darted towards a nearby dune, with me following closely. At the top, Henry paused and barked once more, looking out at the ocean. It was then I noticed the water receding from the shore, a sign of an approaching large wave—a tsunami. The beach was crowded with people. Despite my attempts to alert them by yelling and waving, my efforts went unnoticed. I found myself unable to move, and Henry, showing no further concern, settled beside me and dozed off. Tragically, the tsunami resulted in numerous casualties on the beach that day. Henry had always excelled as a corpse-detection dog, yet this time he sensed the danger earlier than expected.

Imagine finding yourself in a dimly lit room, the air thick with suspense, as you're playing a high-stakes game of Scrabble with none other than the devil himself. The board is set, and tension crackles in the silence until it shatters with a thunderous, "SON OF A BITCH!" The devil's voice booms with frustration, echoing off the walls like a storm. His eyes blaze with fiery contempt as he contemplates upending the board in a fit of rage. 

"Satan, my kids are asleep. Could you keep it down?" I reply, mirroring calm in the face of his wrath. His gaze sharpens, venomous and piercing, as he accuses me of skulduggery. "Did you sneak out ALL of the vowels?" he demands through clenched teeth. I rattle the letter bag, its contents clinking like a truth waiting to be revealed. "Does it sound like letters are missing? Show some decorum, Satan," I retort, my tone a touch icy.

He mutters darkly under his breath, returning to his tiles with a renewed determination. When he finally lays down "glare," I can't help but chuckle, a ripple of amusement in the charged atmosphere. Our words begin to flow freely, a dance of intellect and chance, until I find myself with a lone letter. The devil smirks, basking in his twenty-point lead, a glimmer of triumph in his eyes. 

I place the "X" atop the "I," seizing a triple letter score that shifts the tide. Sinking into my chair, I smile serenely. "XI! That's not a real word!" he

A group of muggers followed a lone individual into an alleyway, unknowingly targeting the worst possible person. I recalled her vividly. The three of us had trailed her with smug confidence, amused by the perceived folly of a girl venturing alone into such a dangerous area at such an hour, only to compound her recklessness by entering an alley. When we demanded her money, she merely sneered at us. "Why would I give you my money?" she questioned, disdain etched across her features as she assessed us. We dismissed her defiance as arrogance, assuming she was merely a rich and spoiled brat. Fools that we were. I inflicted a superficial cut on her cheekbone, not deep, but enough to leave a scar—a reminder meant to instill fear and reinforce her place. Perhaps it would deter her from venturing away from the safety of her parents. I now regret that action deeply.

A sudden splash of water jolted me awake. "No dozing off now!" a bright voice chirped. "You haven't grasped your place yet." There she was, looming over me with a smile, her icy blue eyes piercing through me while the searing brand seared my skin. "There. That should stop the bleeding," she noted casually, as the acrid scent of burnt flesh mingled with blood filled the air. I attempted to scream, but my voice had long since deserted me. Through my remaining eye, I watched her trace the stitches on her cheekbone. "What do you think?" she asked, holding up a mirror. My eye widened at the reflection of my grotesque grin, the flesh peeled back to expose my jaw, reminiscent of Harvey Dent. Why did I have to cut her?

My companions had debts they could never repay, likely marking them as syndicate men now. But my fate was sealed differently—I was at her mercy, trapped for as long as she wanted to toy with me, for as long as she could sustain my life. A few more incisions, and darkness enveloped my vision. The nightmare replayed: a girl wandering in this area, at this time, all alone, only to venture down an alleyway...

This revelation came about quite by accident when a Czarnian named Grobo arrived, determined to create a documentary on the most 'third-world' planet he could find. Initially, Grobo had set his sights on Neptune, but his superiors had informed him that Earth had piqued greater interest. It seems the marketing department had spoken. Grobo, our fictional Czarnian protagonist, made his journey to Earth in the year 2015 AD, synchronizing with the year 666 @ $ in the Czarnian calendar. 

I first encountered Grobo in a dimly lit bar, where he nonchalantly requested a pan-galactic knargle blaster, his towel casually draped over his arm, prepared to dab his mouth after each sip. His confident demeanor suggested he was not one to be underestimated. During our initial interaction, Grobo appraised me with keen curiosity and asked, with a hint of bewilderment, what all the fuss about Earth was.

I responded, quickly clarifying, "No, no, I'm not interested in that sort of thing, no offense." Despite my surprise, I felt a flicker of flattery. The man, evidently puzzled, scanned the bustling street, observing the passersby before settling his gaze back on me. "All you Earthlings look the same on the outside, anyway," he remarked, adopting a more serious tone. "But you're the first one who isn't emitting noxious fumes on the zenith plane." Now, that was a compliment. "Thanks," I replied, uncertain whether to elaborate further.

And yet, the city remained. Despite the fallen bodies and the crimson stains that marked the concrete, our spirits soared and danced where the seven monsters convened. On the first night, our Hero arrived and witnessed the menace of the Puppeteer, whose fingers ensnared our hearts, manipulating them with insidious intimacy; diseases lodged within our very beds. We loved each other with eyes aflame, our souls torn apart by blind desire, until our Hero pried open the Puppeteer's fearsome maw.

On the second night, our Hero pursued the trail of our indulgence, uncovering The Cherub—a spiteful child, bloated and virulent, spewing corrosive bile into our throats. In righteous fury, our Hero set him ablaze. The Cherub was not alone; he had a sibling, the third monster, a metallic creature of gleaming silver, known as The Skitterer. It whispered deceit into our ears, promising dreams easily realized if only we gathered his toxic foliage. Our Hero vanquished this creature, leaving its eight legs suspended in the sky as a lasting testament.

Next emerged the Monkey King, brandishing a sinister staff and cackling with a madness that echoed in our souls. In comparison, we lacked purpose, ambition, and the drive to strive, our willpower fueling the fiend. Yet, our Hero subdued him, wrapping him in his own tail. With the skies cleared, we glimpsed the radiant light of our sisterland—why did our own light not shine with equal brilliance? Our Hero identified the Midas Demon as the cause, a creature whose severed tail still hangs in our sky, a golden testament to the folly of envy.

In the aftermath, our city gleamed with a renewed brightness, drawing flocks of magpies and crows. The Flight adored our streets, as did we, yet we remained ensnared in this new splendor, oblivious as they pecked at our fingers and eyes. Our Hero, undeterred, removed the wings from each one. Then, standing before us, he recounted tales of monstrosities, perils, and evils so vile they incited our hearts to rage, our fists to clench, and our weapons to breathe. At last, we lay spent at his feet, our fury subsided, our blood drained, and yet, emptied of all its monsters, the city remained.

You find yourself perpetually lagging behind life's moments, as if time itself conspires against you. You chase after buses that pull away just as you reach them, witness romantic opportunities slip through your fingers, and traffic lights always seem to turn red just as you approach. Yet, against all odds, there comes a day when you arrive precisely on time. 

"Hello! Welcome to Hell!" greets a surprisingly chipper and voluptuous she-demon, her enthusiasm unsettling in its brightness. Bewildered, you stumble over your words, "What?" The realization hits like a lightning bolt—you're the latest soul to check into the underworld, punctual for perhaps the first time. "Satan has a particular fondness for punctuality," she informs you, her smile unwavering.

"But I'm never on time... Wait, I'm in HELL?!" you exclaim, the reality slowly dawning. "Yes," she confirms with an almost gleeful nod. "Your destination was Heaven, but a tardy arrival meant you missed your chance. Another opening might appear in a few hundred years. But hey, you were right on time for Hell. Lucky you!"

"So let me get this straight," you mutter, still grappling with disbelief, "I died too late for Heaven and I’m stuck here for centuries?" "Yepp!" she chirps, her tone maddeningly buoyant, offering little comfort in your predicament. 

"How did I die?" you inquire, your mind struggling to piece together your final moments. "Ah, you were swept away by a tornado, just as you were about to secure yourself in a root cellar," she explains thoughtfully. "A peculiar choice for someone chronically late to be traversing Tornado Alley."
